I heard a talk yesterday that many of you might have heard at a college campus near you. It was about a girl and guy code named "amy" and "todd". This was an actual case that happened some 10 yrs ago and the story is now told by a lawyer who was in the case.
 
 To make it some what short...
 
 Amy was a 5'4" 125lb girl who was 19 and went out drinking on her college campus. She went to this one house at 11pm where she had 5 beers very quickly. Around 12am she met a guy named Todd who was a 6'0" tall guy around 180lbs. The two began to hit it off and they danced for awhile. Todd asked Amy if she wanted some jello shots and Amy replied yes and Todd came back with 2 jello shots around the 12:30 time frame. The jello shots are special because Todd had helped back them with Everclear (90% alcohol). AMy had 2 and then Todd said that she requested some more. After the 5th one (at this time close to 2am) Amy ran outside throwing up. Todd had just gone away for a second and when he came back he went to find her. He found her outside throwing up and Amy asked to be taken home. Todd agreed and took her back to her home. Todd began to leave when Amy called back and asked for a glass of water...Todd agreed and gave her the glass of water. He then proceeded to leave again. Then Amy said "wait" and grabbed him and gave him a big kiss which led to some more... Any then ran off to the bathroom where she began to throw up some more. She came back BRUSHED HER TEETH and the two started to go at it again. Before they were about to engage in sex, Amy said she didn't want to because she might throw up everywhere. Todd said he was "beyond the point of no return". Amy still said no and Todd agreed. Amy then said she would get some rest until she felt better and then they would finish what they started. Todd testified that he sat for 20-30min watching TV while Amy was "passed out". She then woke up and said she FELT A LOT BETTER. She then began to make out with Todd again and the two engaged in sex at this point. Afterwards Amy went to bed and Todd left his name, number, and a note saying he had a wonderful time and wanted to see her again. The next morning Amy woke up hung over and saw the note. She didn't remember anything from last night and asked her roommate if she met a guy named Todd. Her roommate said "no" because her roommate was out all night. AMy then called the number and Todd, excited to see she called back so quickly, answered. Amy was confused and said she remember nothing. Todd then explained everything that happened between the two. Later on, because Amy was a virgin at the time, she went to the hospital on the advice of the police and later charges were filed against Todd for sexual assualt in the 2nd degree.
 
 Is Todd Guilty?
 
 If you know this case please don't give it away.
 If you have questions, ask me.
 
 The Law:
 Someone can't consent to sex if the person has reason to believe the other is MENTALLY INCAPACITATED or if the person SHOULD KNOW the other is MENTALLY INCAPACITATED. 
 
 It is important to note a few things:
 1) Being drunk is not mentally incapacitated. SEE LINK
 http://4forums.com/political/showpost.php?p=172042&postcount=35
 2) It is what the OTHER person(Todd) SHOULD HAVE KNOWN or DID KNOW at the time...not what was the actual state of Amy now that we know.
 3) They engaged in sex around 5:30am...3hr30min after she threw up the first time (which was after the 5th jello shot)
 4) Mentally incapacitated means the person doesn't have the ability to make rational judgements or think in a rational manner.
 5) She did "consent" and did partcipate in the sex...there is not question here about "no" meaning "no"..it is more about "yes" meaning "yes"
 6) He was a Bartender partime
 
 I'll lt some discuss it for a bit before I tell you guys the verdict and outcome. 
 
 The audience I was in had 600 people...it was 50/50 for those that thought guilty or not guilty....Gender, race, or age didn't seem to matter in this figure.
 
 --I WILL POST THE VERDICT ON SUNDAY NIGHT AND THE REASON GIVEN TO ME FOR THE OUTCOME. I WILL ALSO GIVE MY VIEW AT THIS TIME AND POST LINKS TO THE SPEAKERS WEBPAGE AND NEWS ARTICLES.--
 A special thanks to the speaker for talking about this very important issue

 Not to be rude to you but I commented on this in my first post.
 
 
1) Being drunk is not mentally incapacitated.
 
 
 She was obviously in the mental incapacitated state but it matters about whether he KNEW this or SHOULD HAVE KNOWN this. Being drunk, however, is not always being mentally incapacitated. For example, you can be drunk and sign a contract and still have it be legal binding. However! If you are mentally incapacitated you don't have the ability to reason or make rational choices. The question from this becomes:
 
 Did Todd KNOW she was mentally incapacitated or SHOULD HE HAVE KNOWN that she was mentally incapacitated. 
 
 I see this two ways.
 
 Did Todd have reason to believe that Amy was drunk but able to understand what she was doing in a way? She obviously didn't have a full ability to reason but a full ability of reason is not required. You can be dead tired no sleeping for 4 days and have a pretty limited ability to reason but you are not mentally incapacitated.
 
 Or Did Todd have have reason to believe that Amy was mentally incapacitated to a small degree. The thing is, do you need some evidence to show she was mentally incapacatiated or evidence to show that she wasn't? 
 
 These are two sides:
 Evidence to show she was just drunk but had rational judgment- She brushed her teeth because she knew her breath was bad, She knew she would get sick if she had sex, she asked for a glass of water to make her feel better, she knew how to tell todd directions back to her place. 
 Evidence to show she was without rational judgment and thus mentally incapacitated- She had 20 drinks total....5x3 for the jello shots and 5 beers, She threw up which actually makes you drunker, Todd was a bartender which could mean he should know her state(this could go either way actually), She passed out for a time of 30min.
 
 I think you were on the correct track of thinking though. Hopefully this clears up some things. All of this was presented in the Q/A session before we voted by the way.

The first issue here is whether or not being drunk is being mentally incapacitated.....the answer in some states is ...YES! So my next question would be what state are we talking about....for instance in VA.
 
 §27-1-16. ""Incapacitated" means a level of intoxication at which an individual is incapable of physical or mental control of himself, thus rendering him dangerous to himself or others or unable to protect himself from hazard."
 
 I would beg to sat she was incapacitated....so by that definition of the law...yes it was asult. He should have recognized she was not making clear decisions......
 
 here is the law is Kentucky....
 
 2. Victim's Incapacity to Consent
 In addition to forcible compulsion, lack of consent by the victim to the sexual act can also result from an incapacity to consent to the act. A person is deemed incapable of consent when he is: less than sixteen years old, mentally retarded or suffers from a mental illness, is mentally incapacitated, or is physically helpless. KRS 510.020: 
 
 -a "mentally retarded person" means "a person with significantly subaverage general intellectual functioning existing concurrently with deficits in adaptive behavior and manifested during the developmental period, as defined in KRS Chapter 202B." KRS 510.010(5). 
 -"mentally incapacitated" is defined as a person "rendered temporarily incapable of appraising or controlling his conduct as a result of the influence of a controlled or intoxicating substance administered to him without his consent or as a result of any other act committed upon him without his consent." KRS 510.010(5). Note that this definition specifically requires an additional element of nonconsent on the part of the victim: that the victim did not consent to receiving the intoxicating substance. 
 -"Physically helpless" requires that the victim be "unconscious or for any other reason is physically unable to communicate unwillingness to an act." KRS 510.010(6)
 
 
 just my two cents if that chanvges anyones mind about their stance..
 
 She was in fact mentally incapacitated in the eyes of the law.....

Cone

I would vote that Todd was guilty of the crime he was charged with because I feel like he violated the particular statute in question. Mainly, I believe that Todd should have known that Amy was incapacitated, and I believe so for two reasons. The first reason is that Todd was a bartender, and the second reason is that he contributed to the making of the supercharged jello shots. These two facts lead me to believe that, given all the events Todd witnessed throughout the course of the evening, he should have known that Amy was incapacitated.
 
 Given the nature of the specific issue, we necessarily receive a picture of Amy as victim, and given the particular point of law in question, I think it evident that she was. However, I also think it evident that Amy's lifestyle choice placed her in the position of victim in this trial. As she was drinking at the age of 19, Amy was in clear violation of the law (as was Todd on this point as well). I think it clear then that Amy's willingness to violate the law led to her condition of incapacity. I do not suppose this to completely alleviate Todd of all responsibility, but I do suggest that Amy is more than partially responsible for the incident.
 
 It seems as though this point has fallen through the cracks during this discussion. I do find it mind-boggling that Amy seems to only invoke a position toward the law that endorses the outcome she desires. By that I mean that on the one hand Amy seems to have no problem with the lack of enforcement of one statute (the one prohibiting underage drinking), while on the other hand desiring another point of law to be strictly enforced (the aggravated assault statutes). And, not surprisingly, her schizophrenic view of the enforcement of statutes is always in alignment with the way she desires to live. "Don't drink while underage," one may say. "But I want to. Those laws are stupid anyway," Amy replies. "Well then, you may find yourself in the position of consenting to sexual activity when you probably wouldn't have were you not drinking," the reply goes." "How dare someone do that to me," she says, "Aren't there laws prohibiting that?"
 
 Again, I do not suppose that Amy's lifestyle choices alleviate Todd of all responsibility. However, Amy's actions were in violation of the law, making her a criminal just like Todd.

Being a bartender, or even just a reasonably experienced person, Todd should have realised that Amy was extremely intoxicated.
 
 The one question I have is, was Amy mentally incapacitated? On the one hand, being drunk is not mentally incapacitated. On the other, she exibits several of the examples of incapacitation, such as the smell of alcohol on the breath, vomiting, outrageous or unusual behavior and unconsciousness.
 
 Todd should have realised that after those 20 drinks, even three hours later, Amy would have been very, very drunk. The question is, would he have realised that she may have been drunk enough to be mentally incapacitated? The fact that he tried to leave, and that she restrained him, would indicated to me that he realised she was too drunk.
 
 Using this set of tests: Who, What, When, Where, Why and How, I would have to say that Amy was probably not incapacitated. 
 
 I would also suggest that Todd should have been able to make an accurate estimation of her state of mind. He knew how much she had had to drink, and would have been able to watch her behaviour change as the night progressed, and has the practical experience of being a bartender.
 
 The question is, I believe: Should Todd have believed that Amy was mentally incapacitated? My anser is a tentative no. She asked him to stay, demonstrated enough understanding to brush her teeth, understood that she may vomit during sex, understood enough to consent to sex. She knew who she was with, where she was, what they were doing and (one can only assume) why they were doing it. Were I in his place, I probably would not have assumed mental incapacitation either. Not to say I would have slept with her, but there you go.

This is the only significant question in relation to the aggravated assault in the second degree given the circumstances of the case.

I thank you guys for all of your input and comments on what you thought the outcome should be. I actually feel this is very important for people to hear; even more so if they are in or going to be in college. There are a lot of things to learn from this case and a few I would like to point out right now.
 
 Rape is not sexual assault. The speaker actually used these terms interchangably as well but stated at the beginning how differenet they are and that it is important to know this. Rape has a strict definition and this would never fit rape. Sexual assault is could be said to be "pre rape" or "rape light" or something like that. This would be like touching a little kid in bad areas...that is sexual assault. Rape would be actually having sexual intercourse with the little kid. From that extreme example you can see the difference.
 
 Another thing, Drunk doesn't mean you can't enter into a contract. Drunk is a legal term which (in VA) means .08 blood alcohol level. You can actually enter in a contract drunk. Mentally incapacitated is a different story. This means you can identify who, what, where, when, why, and how for situations . Hopefully you guys can see and maybe even learn the difference.
 
 
 Also a special thanks to the speaker Attorney Brett Sokolow who told this case in front of 600 people and tells many across the US.

Steeeeve

The case between Todd and Amy was one that is rarely heard in court but is very common on the college campus. There was a lot of evidence to go by and it appears most of you think he should have been "not guilty". In the audience I was in, it was more like 50/50.
 
 The jury got the case and decided it in 7 hours. The came back with a verdict that was probably not too shocking....Guilty. Todd was found guilty on 2nd degree sexual assault. Both him and Amy were charged and convicted for underage drinking. Todd was sentenced to 18 months in jail for his crime. He also had to register on the sex offender list and will be on that list for life. Todd was kicked out of school which happened to be one of the top 10 schools IN THE WORLD. Todd also is a registered Felon. Amy stayed in school for a bit but later dropped out. She has actually been to see one of speaches Attorney Brett Sokolow gives. 
 
 Many might ask, why was Todd convicted? Well, believe it or not, Cone actually got most of the reasons correct. The jury found that it would be hard to say whether or not Todd knew of Amy's condition but the fact is, he SHOULD HAVE KNOWN. The jury felt that since Todd was a bartender, gave her the jello shots that HE made AND saw her condition the whole night that any REASONABLE person would come to the conclusion that she was mentally incapacitated.
 
 
 My Opinion:
 
 I have had a week to reflect on this case and hear others argue their points about whether he is guilty or not guilty. To be honest, it doesn't surprise me that he was guilty. I could easily see him being guilty actually. The juries job was to find what a reasonable person should have known in this situation. I think with different people this might have made a different outcome. I feel that a reasonable person could have reason to believe that Amy was "drunk" but not really "gone". She fact that she brushed her teeth and told him not to leave seems irrelevant to me because I believe she was pretty wasted at this point. However, she passed out for 30 minutes and woke up which makes me believe that she was ok. I have never seen anyone who was really bad off only pass out for 30minutes. I have seen a person that had too much to drink be awake and alert but it was clear she was mentally incapacitated. The girl I saw was saying she "wanted to save the baby" and really had no idea what was going on. In this case, Amy, seemed to have some understanding of "who, what, where, when, why, and how". She knew WHO Todd was, She seemed to know WHAT she was doing, She knew WHERE her apartment was, she seemed to know WHEN she would be better, she seemed to know WHY she couldn't have sex at first, she knew HOW to have sex as she was involved in the sex. All this does is leave reasonable doubt in my mind that Todd could have believed Amy was just drunk and not completly gone like the girl I had seen.
 
 The thing that angers me the most though is not that Todd was guilty, because I could see a reasonable person convicting him, but rather the punishment Todd got. Todd and Amy both FAILED the personal responsbility test. Neither one took the time to be responsible for their actions and to their actions to help another person. The fact that both of them were doing something illegal was what caused this whole thing to happen. In the end Todd paid for the his mistakes plus the mistakes of Amy. I hold Amy responsible for ruining Todds life. I hold Todd responsible for ruining Amy's life although Todds seemed to be more of a loss. If the outcome was 30 days or something and NOT on the sex offender list, I might have been ok with it. The fact that Amy felt she was victim is totally false. She was just as much a victim as Todd in my opinion. Justice would be done if Amy had to serve 2 yrs as well. Truely a sad situation.
 
 One last point. The sex offender list is the list that Todd is on. This list has people that have raped 5 random women and people like Todd. The amount of people on the list that are like Todd is actually bigger then many might think. I spoke with a psychologist the other day and he told me that people like Todd and other lower degree sex offenders really don't have a high re-offense rate. The news tends to show the rare ones that will reoffend. Now doesn't this make the list useless? If you lived next to Todd you would believe he raped a girl without ever knowing the truth. Is this fair? I would say not.
 
 
 
 I hope this case has been helpful to some. I hope some of you will learn to maybe be responsible for keeping yourself out of this situation.
Adept

Bearing the verdict, and the reasons for it in mind, I still believe Todd was innocent. He should have known (and probably did know) how much she had to drink. But given her actions over the evening, I would not have considered her to be mentally incapacitated.
Eddie

That's largely because incapactiated men have great difficulty getting it up...

 
 Hehe... you need to be pretty hammered for that effect to kick in.
JPSartre12

Bearing the verdict, and the reasons for it in mind, I still believe Todd was innocent. He should have known (and probably did know) how much she had to drink. But given her actions over the evening, I would not have considered her to be mentally incapacitated.

 
 Agreed. It just shows you that any verdict is possible given the right mixture of jurors. Look at the OJ trial, for example.
Wez

Hehe... you need to be pretty hammered for that effect to kick in.

 I think it's a safety mechanism. If you're that drunk, you don't know what you're getting with. You'll be glad in the morning.:)
 
 -Wez
